name: Negation, Not
meaning: The logical opposite of a statement. If P is true, ¬P is false.
example: It is not raining outside.

name: Conjunction, And
meaning: True only if both connected statements are true.
example: The sun is shining and the birds are singing.

name: Disjunction, Or
meaning: True if at least one of the connected statements is true.
example: For lunch, I will have a sandwich or a salad.

name: Exclusive Disjunction, XOR
meaning: True if exactly one of the connected statements is true, but not both.
example: You can have either the soup or the salad, but not both.

name: Material Conditional, If...then...
meaning: If P, then Q. False only when P is true and Q is false.
example: If you press the button, then the light will turn on.

name: Biconditional, If and only if (iff)
meaning: True if both statements have the same truth value.
example: You can vote if and only if you are a registered citizen.

name: Tautology, Top, Verum
meaning: A statement that is always true.
example: Either the team will win or the team will not win.

name: Contradiction, Bottom, Falsum
meaning: A statement that is always false.
example: My car is completely red and my car is completely blue.

name: Turnstile, Provable
meaning: The statement on the right can be formally proven from the statements on the left.
example: From the given axioms, we can prove the theorem.

name: Double Turnstile, Models, Entails
meaning: The statement on the right is a logical consequence of the statements on the left.
example: The premises 'All humans are mortal' and 'Socrates is a human' logically imply 'Socrates is mortal'.

name: Does not model
meaning: The statement on the right is not a logical consequence of the statement on the left.
example: The fact that the grass is wet does not logically imply that it rained; it could have been sprinklers.

name: Not provable
meaning: The statement on the right cannot be formally proven from the statements on the left.
example: It is not provable from the axioms that the project will finish on time.

name: Therefore
meaning: Indicates a conclusion.
example: All birds have feathers; a robin is a bird; therefore, a robin has feathers.

name: Because, Since
meaning: Indicates a reason or premise.
example: The ground is wet because it has been raining.

name: NAND, Sheffer Stroke
meaning: Not And. False only if both statements are true.
example: It is not the case that I have both time and money for a vacation right now.

name: NOR, Peirce Arrow
meaning: Not Or. True only if both statements are false.
example: He wants neither fame nor fortune.

name: NAND, Sheffer Stroke
meaning: Not And. False only if both statements are true.
example: It is not the case that I have both time and money for a vacation right now.

name: NOR, Peirce Arrow
meaning: Not Or. True only if both statements are false.
example: He wants neither fame nor fortune.

name: Universal Quantifier, For all
meaning: The statement is true for every element in a domain.
example: All cats have whiskers.

name: Existential Quantifier, There exists
meaning: There is at least one element in a domain for which the statement is true.
example: There is a key that opens this door.

name: Non-existence, There does not exist
meaning: There is no element in a domain for which the statement is true.
example: There is no perfect solution to this problem.

name: Uniqueness Quantifier, There exists exactly one
meaning: There is one and only one element for which the statement is true.
example: There is exactly one winner in the race.

name: Box, Necessity
meaning: The statement is necessarily true (true in all possible worlds).
example: It is necessary that squares have four sides.

name: Diamond, Possibility
meaning: The statement is possibly true (true in at least one possible world).
example: It is possible that we will go to the movies tonight.

name: Contingent, Possibly Not
meaning: It is possible for the statement to be false.
example: It is possible that I will not pass the exam if I don't study.

name: Not Necessary, Contingent
meaning: The statement is not necessarily true (equivalent to ◇¬).
example: It is not necessary for you to attend the meeting, but it is encouraged.

name: Globally, Always (Gφ)
meaning: The statement φ is true now and at all future times.
example: The network connection must always be active.

name: Finally, Eventually (Fφ)
meaning: The statement φ will be true at some point in the future.
example: Your package will eventually be delivered.

name: Historically (Hφ)
meaning: The statement φ has been true at all points in the past.
example: The vault has always been secure.

name: Previously, Once (Pφ)
meaning: The statement φ was true at some point in the past.
example: An error once occurred in the system.

name: Next (Xφ)
meaning: The statement φ will be true in the very next time step.
example: The light will turn green at the next state.

name: Until
meaning: A statement φ holds true until a statement ψ becomes true.
example: The alarm will stay on until the system is reset.

name: Obligation (Oφ)
meaning: It is obligatory that φ; you ought to do φ.
example: It is obligatory to wear a seatbelt.

name: Permission (Pφ)
meaning: It is permissible to do φ.
example: It is permissible to take photos here.

name: Forbidden (Fφ)
meaning: It is forbidden to do φ.
example: It is forbidden to smoke indoors.

name: Knowledge (Agent a knows φ)
meaning: Agent 'a' knows that statement φ is true.
example: Alice knows that it is Monday.

name: Belief (Agent a believes φ)
meaning: Agent 'a' believes that statement φ is true.
example: Bob believes that his team will win.

name: Common Knowledge (in Group G)
meaning: Everyone in group G knows φ, knows that everyone knows φ, etc.
example: It is common knowledge among the staff that the meeting is mandatory.

name: Element of, In
meaning: An object is a member of a set.
example: Canada is an element of the set of North American countries.

name: Not an element of
meaning: An object is not a member of a set.
example: A carrot is not an element of the set of fruits.

name: Subset
meaning: All elements of the first set are also in the second set.
example: The set of dogs is a subset of the set of mammals.

name: Proper Subset
meaning: The first set is a subset of the second, but is not equal to it.
example: The set of even numbers is a proper subset of the set of all integers.

name: Superset
meaning: The first set contains all elements of the second set.
example: The set of mammals is a superset of the set of dogs.

name: Proper Superset
meaning: The first set is a superset of the second, but is not equal to it.
example: The set of all integers is a proper superset of the set of even numbers.

name: Empty Set, Null Set
meaning: The set that contains no elements.
example: The set of all fish that can fly is the empty set.

name: The Empty Set, Set Braces
meaning: The set that contains no elements. Also used to define sets.
example: The list of my pet dragons is { }.

name: Intersection
meaning: The set of elements that are common to both sets.
example: The intersection of the morning shift and the evening shift is empty.

name: Union
meaning: The set of all elements that are in at least one of the sets.
example: The team is the union of the design department and the marketing department.

name: Set Difference
meaning: The set of elements in the first set but not in the second.
example: The set of all students minus the set of students who passed gives you those who failed.

name: Cartesian Product
meaning: The set of all possible ordered pairs from two sets.
example: A standard deck of cards is the Cartesian product of ranks and suits.

name: Power Set
meaning: The set of all possible subsets of a set.
example: All possible pizza topping combinations come from the power set of available toppings.

name: Cardinality, Size of A
meaning: The number of elements in set A.
example: The cardinality of the set of continents is 7.

name: Bottom element, Minimum
meaning: The smallest element in a partially ordered set.
example: In the set of divisors of 12 ordered by divisibility, 1 is the bottom element.

name: Top element, Maximum
meaning: The largest element in a partially ordered set.
example: In the set of divisors of 12 ordered by divisibility, 12 is the top element.

name: Precedes
meaning: An element comes before another in a strict partial order.
example: In the project plan, the 'Design' phase precedes the 'Build' phase.

name: Succeeds
meaning: An element comes after another in a strict partial order.
example: In the project plan, the 'Test' phase succeeds the 'Build' phase.

name: Is equal to
meaning: The two objects are identical or have the same value.
example: Two plus two is equal to four.

name: Is not equal to
meaning: The two objects are not identical or do not have the same value.
example: A square is not equal to a circle.

name: Is congruent to, Is equivalent to
meaning: Two objects are equivalent in some sense (e.g., in modular arithmetic or by definition).
example: A triangle is defined as a polygon with three sides.

name: Not identical to
meaning: Two objects are not identical or congruent.
example: Although they look similar, this shape is not identical to that one.

name: Is approximately equal to
meaning: The two values are very close to each other.
example: The population of the city is approximately equal to 1.5 million.

name: Is isomorphic to, Is congruent to
meaning: Two structures are fundamentally the same, or two shapes are the same size and shape.
example: This triangle is congruent to that one; you can place it directly on top.

name: Is defined as
meaning: The term on the left is being defined by the expression on the right.
example: Let 'c' be defined as the speed of light.

name: Assignment, Is defined as
meaning: The term on the left is being defined or assigned the value on the right.
example: Let the variable 'score' be assigned the value 100.

name: Is related to, Equivalence relation
meaning: Indicates that two objects are related by some equivalence relation.
example: Having the same birthday is an equivalence relation among people.

name: Is related to, Proportional to
meaning: Indicates that two objects are related by some equivalence or similarity relation.
example: As a rule of thumb, the cost of the repair is related to the age of the car.

name: Probability of event A
meaning: The likelihood of event A occurring.
example: The probability of flipping heads on a fair coin is 50%.

name: Conditional Probability
meaning: The probability of event A occurring given that event B has already occurred.
example: The probability of it being cloudy, given that it is raining, is very high.

name: Complementary Event
meaning: The event that A does not occur.
example: If A is 'rolling a 6', then Aᶜ is 'rolling a 1, 2, 3, 4, or 5'.

name: Is proportional to
meaning: One quantity is a constant multiple of another.
example: The amount of paint needed is proportional to the area of the wall.

name: Expected Value of X
meaning: The long-run average value of a random variable X.
example: The expected value of a single roll of a standard die is 3.5.

name: Variance of X
meaning: A measure of how spread out the values of a random variable X are.
example: The two classes have the same average score, but the variance is higher in the second class, meaning the scores are more spread out.

name: Standard Deviation
meaning: The square root of the variance, a measure of data spread.
example: The test scores had an average of 85 with a standard deviation of 5 points.

name: Entropy of X
meaning: A measure of the uncertainty or randomness of a random variable.
example: The entropy of a fair coin flip is higher than that of a biased coin, because the outcome is more uncertain.

name: Mutual Information
meaning: A measure of the shared information between two random variables.
example: There is high mutual information between a person's height and their weight.

name: Conditional Expectation
meaning: The expected value of one variable given the value of another.
example: The conditional expectation of a student's final grade, given they passed the midterm, is higher than the overall average.

name: Lambda Abstraction, Function Definition
meaning: An anonymous function that takes an argument 'x' and returns the expression 'E'.
example: To double a number, you can use the function λx. x * 2.

name: Function Application
meaning: Applying the function 'f' to the argument 'x'.
example: Applying the 'square' function to '3' is written as (square 3).

name: Function Type
meaning: A function that takes an input of type α and returns an output of type β.
example: A function that takes an Integer and returns a String has the type Integer → String.

name: Function Composition
meaning: Combines two functions into one; (f ∘ g)(x) = f(g(x)).
example: The operation 'wash and dry' is a composition of the 'wash' function followed by the 'dry' function.

name: Identity Function
meaning: A function that returns its input unchanged; id(x) = x.
example: The identity function for photocopying is a machine that outputs a perfect copy of the original document.

name: Maps to
meaning: Used in function definitions to show how an element is transformed.
example: The function f(x) = x² maps the element 3 to the element 9.

name: Vector, Tends to
meaning: Represents a vector or convergence in the weak sense.
example: The force applied to the object is represented by a vector pointing right.

name: Contour Integral, Closed Line Integral
meaning: An integral along a closed curve in the complex plane or a vector field.
example: The closed line integral of a conservative field like gravity around any path is always zero.

name: Aleph-naught
meaning: The cardinality of the set of natural numbers; the smallest infinity.
example: The number of integers is aleph-naught, a countably infinite amount.

name: Aleph-one
meaning: The cardinality of the set of all countable ordinal numbers; the next infinity after ℵ₀.
example: Under the continuum hypothesis, aleph-one is the size of the set of all real numbers.

name: Partial Derivative
meaning: The rate of change of a multi-variable function with respect to one of its variables.
example: To find how a company's profit changes with just advertising costs, we'd take the partial derivative with respect to advertising.

name: Closure of A
meaning: The smallest closed set containing the set A.
example: The closure of the open interval (0, 1) is the closed interval [0, 1], which includes the endpoints.

name: Tensor Product
meaning: A complex way of 'multiplying' vector spaces or modules.
example: The combined state of two quantum particles is represented by the tensor product of their individual states.

name: Direct Sum
meaning: A way of combining mathematical structures (like groups or vector spaces) into a larger one.
example: The 3D space we live in can be seen as the direct sum of three perpendicular lines (axes).

name: Interior Subset
meaning: A is a subset of the interior of B.
example: The house itself is an interior subset of the entire fenced property.

name: Symmetric Difference
meaning: The set of elements which are in either of the sets, but not in their intersection.
example: The list of people who are subscribed to either the newspaper or the magazine, but not both, is the symmetric difference of the two subscriber lists.

name: Complement
meaning: The set of all elements in the universal set that are not in set A.
example: If the universe is all students, the complement of students who passed is the set of students who failed.

name: Disjoint Union
meaning: The union of sets that are assumed to be disjoint (have no common elements).
example: The total student body is the disjoint union of the freshmen, sophomores, juniors, and seniors.

name: Divides
meaning: a | b means 'a divides b', so b is a multiple of a.
example: Since 3 divides 12, we can split 12 cookies evenly among 3 friends.

name: Does not divide
meaning: a ∤ b means 'a does not divide b'.
example: Since 5 does not divide 12, we cannot split 12 cookies evenly among 5 friends without breaking them.

name: Greatest Common Divisor
meaning: The largest positive integer that divides both a and b.
example: To simplify the fraction 12/18, we find the greatest common divisor of 12 and 18, which is 6.

name: Least Common Multiple
meaning: The smallest positive integer that is a multiple of both a and b.
example: If two gears with 8 and 12 teeth mesh, they will return to their starting position after the least common multiple of 8 and 12, which is 24 rotations.

name: Congruence modulo n
meaning: a and b have the same remainder when divided by n.
example: A 12-hour clock works with congruence modulo 12; 15 o'clock is congruent to 3 o'clock.

name: Integral
meaning: Represents the area under a curve, or the accumulation of quantities.
example: To find the total distance traveled from a velocity-time graph, we calculate the integral of the velocity function.

name: Derivative
meaning: Measures the instantaneous rate of change of a function.
example: The derivative of a position function gives you the instantaneous velocity of an object.

name: Limit
meaning: The value that a function approaches as the input approaches some value.
example: The limit of a car's speed as it brakes is zero.

name: Infinity
meaning: An abstract concept describing something without any bound or larger than any real number.
example: The set of all natural numbers is of infinite size.

name: Nabla, Gradient
meaning: The vector of partial derivatives, pointing in the direction of the greatest rate of increase of a scalar field.
example: The gradient of a topographical map points directly uphill.

name: Laplace Operator, Laplacian
meaning: The divergence of the gradient, used to model phenomena like diffusion and wave propagation.
example: The heat equation uses the Laplacian to describe how temperature distributes over time.

name: Summation
meaning: The addition of a sequence of numbers.
example: The total cost of your shopping list is the summation of the prices of all items.

name: Product
meaning: The multiplication of a sequence of numbers.
example: The probability of several independent events all happening is the product of their individual probabilities.

name: Vector
meaning: A mathematical object that has both magnitude and direction.
example: The velocity of the wind can be represented by a vector, showing its speed and direction.

name: Transpose
meaning: A matrix obtained by flipping it over its main diagonal.
example: In a spreadsheet, taking the transpose is like switching the rows and columns.

name: Dot Product
meaning: A scalar value that is the product of the magnitudes of two vectors and the cosine of the angle between them.
example: The work done by a force is the dot product of the force vector and the displacement vector.

name: Cross Product
meaning: A vector that is perpendicular to two given vectors.
example: The torque on a bolt from a wrench is calculated using the cross product of the force and the lever arm vector.

name: Determinant
meaning: A scalar value that can be computed from the elements of a square matrix, representing the scaling factor of the linear transformation.
example: If the determinant of a system of equations is zero, it means there is no unique solution.

name: Norm, Magnitude
meaning: The length or size of a vector.
example: The norm of a velocity vector is the object's speed.

name: Dimension
meaning: The number of vectors in any basis for the vector space.
example: The space we live in has a dimension of 3, because you need three coordinates (length, width, height) to specify a point.

name: Kernel
meaning: The set of vectors that are mapped to the zero vector by a linear transformation.
example: In a 3D to 2D projection, the kernel is the line of points that all collapse onto the origin.

name: Image
meaning: The set of all possible output vectors of a linear transformation.
example: The image of a 3D to 2D projection is the entire 2D plane that is being projected onto.

name: Inner Product
meaning: A generalization of the dot product that defines geometric concepts like length and angle.
example: The inner product is used in signal processing to measure how similar two signals are.

name: Angle
meaning: The figure formed by two rays meeting at a common endpoint.
example: The angle between the two hands of a clock at 3:00 is 90 degrees.

name: Perpendicular, Orthogonal
meaning: Two lines or vectors are at a right angle (90 degrees) to each other.
example: The wall is perpendicular to the floor.

name: Parallel
meaning: Two lines in a plane that do not meet.
example: The two rails of a train track are parallel.

name: Degree
meaning: A unit of measurement for angles.
example: A full circle has 360 degrees.

name: Triangle
meaning: A polygon with three edges and three vertices.
example: The sail on the boat is shaped like a triangle.

name: Similarity
meaning: Two geometric shapes are similar if they have the same shape, but possibly different sizes.
example: A photograph is similar to the real-life scene it captures.

name: Group Operation
meaning: A binary operation on a set that satisfies certain axioms (closure, associativity, identity, invertibility).
example: Addition is the group operation for the set of integers.

name: Isomorphism
meaning: A structure-preserving mapping between two algebraic structures.
example: The group of integers under addition is isomorphic to the group of even integers under addition, they have the same structure.

name: Normal Subgroup
meaning: A subgroup that is invariant under conjugation by members of the group of which it is a part.
example: In the group of symmetries of a square, the subgroup of rotations is a normal subgroup.

name: Quotient Group
meaning: A group obtained by aggregating similar elements of a larger group using an equivalence relation.
example: The quotient group of integers modulo n describes clock arithmetic.

name: Homomorphism
meaning: A structure-preserving map between two algebraic structures of the same type.
example: A homomorphism maps the identity element of the first group to the identity element of the second group.

name: Automorphism Group
meaning: The group of all isomorphisms from a group to itself.
example: The automorphism group measures the symmetries of an object.

name: Integers
meaning: The set of whole numbers and their opposites (..., -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, ...).
example: The change in temperature, in degrees, is always an integer.

name: Rational Numbers
meaning: The set of numbers that can be expressed as a fraction p/q of two integers.
example: Any measurement made with a standard ruler is a rational number.

name: Real Numbers
meaning: The set of all rational and irrational numbers.
example: The height of a person can be any real number within a certain range.

name: Complex Numbers
meaning: Numbers that can be expressed in the form a + bi, where a and b are real numbers and i is the imaginary unit.
example: Complex numbers are used in electrical engineering to analyze AC circuits.

name: Natural Numbers
meaning: The set of positive integers (1, 2, 3, ...), sometimes including 0.
example: The number of people in a room is a natural number.

name: Pi
meaning: The ratio of a circle's circumference to its diameter, approximately 3.14159.
example: To find the area of a circular pizza, you need to use pi.

name: Euler's Number
meaning: The base of the natural logarithm, approximately 2.71828.
example: Euler's number is used to model continuous growth, like compound interest or population growth.

name: Golden Ratio
meaning: A special number approximately equal to 1.618, often found in art, architecture, and nature.
example: The proportions of the Parthenon are said to exhibit the golden ratio.

name: Imaginary Unit
meaning: The number whose square is -1.
example: The imaginary unit is a fundamental part of complex numbers used in wave mechanics.

name: Square Root
meaning: A number that, when multiplied by itself, gives the original number.
example: The side length of a square with area 25 is the square root of 25, which is 5.

name: Factorial
meaning: The product of all positive integers up to a given number.
example: The number of ways to arrange 5 books on a shelf is 5 factorial (120).

name: Absolute Value
meaning: The distance of a number from zero on the number line.
example: Whether you take 5 steps forward or 5 steps back, the absolute value of your displacement is 5 steps.

name: Sine
meaning: In a right triangle, the ratio of the length of the side opposite an angle to the length of the hypotenuse.
example: Sine waves are used to model the oscillation of a pendulum.

name: Cosine
meaning: In a right triangle, the ratio of the length of the adjacent side to the length of the hypotenuse.
example: Cosine is used in computer graphics to calculate lighting on surfaces.

name: Tangent
meaning: In a right triangle, the ratio of the length of the opposite side to the length of the adjacent side.
example: We can find the height of a building by measuring the angle of elevation and using the tangent function.

name: Logarithm
meaning: The exponent to which a base must be raised to produce a given number.
example: The Richter scale for earthquakes uses a logarithm to measure their severity.

name: Natural Logarithm
meaning: A logarithm to the base e.
example: The time it takes for a radioactive substance to decay is calculated using the natural logarithm.

name: Exponential Function
meaning: The function e^x, where e is Euler's number.
example: The spread of a virus can often be modeled with an exponential function.

name: Function
meaning: A relation between a set of inputs and a set of permissible outputs with the property that each input is related to exactly one output.
example: Your final grade is a function of your test scores.

name: Big O Notation
meaning: Describes the upper bound of the time or space complexity of an algorithm.
example: A simple search through a list has a Big O of n, because in the worst case you have to check every item.

name: Big Omega Notation
meaning: Describes the lower bound of the time or space complexity of an algorithm.
example: Any algorithm that has to read all its inputs must have a complexity of at least Big Omega of n.

name: Big Theta Notation
meaning: Describes a tight bound on the time or space complexity of an algorithm.
example: An algorithm with a complexity of Big Theta of n log n will perform consistently, without huge variations between best and worst cases.

name: Little o Notation
meaning: An upper bound that is not tight. The function grows strictly slower than the bound.
example: A function that grows logarithmically is little o of n because it grows much slower than linearly.

name: Little omega Notation
meaning: A lower bound that is not tight. The function grows strictly faster than the bound.
example: An exponential function is little omega of n because it grows much faster than linearly.

name: Join, Supremum
meaning: The least upper bound of a subset of elements in a partially ordered set.
example: In a hierarchy of managers, the join of two employees is their lowest common manager.

name: Meet, Infimum
meaning: The greatest lower bound of a subset of elements in a partially ordered set.
example: In a family tree, the meet of two siblings is the set of their parents.

name: Less than or equal to
meaning: Indicates that one value is smaller than or identical to another.
example: To get a discount, your purchase must be less than or equal to $100.

name: Greater than or equal to
meaning: Indicates that one value is larger than or identical to another.
example: You must be greater than or equal to 18 years old to vote.

name: Alpha
meaning: Often used to represent angles, coefficients, or a significance level in statistics.
example: In our statistical test, we set the alpha level to 0.05.

name: Beta
meaning: Often used to represent angles, coefficients in regression, or the probability of a Type II error in statistics.
example: The beta coefficient in our model shows the effect of advertising on sales.

name: Gamma
meaning: Used for the Gamma function in mathematics or gamma rays in physics.
example: The gamma distribution is often used to model waiting times.

name: Delta
meaning: Represents change, difference, or the discriminant of a polynomial.
example: Delta-V is the change in velocity needed for a spacecraft to perform a maneuver.

name: Epsilon
meaning: Represents a small positive quantity, especially in limits and proofs.
example: For the limit to exist, the function's value must be within epsilon of L.

name: Zeta
meaning: Known for the Riemann Zeta function, related to the distribution of prime numbers.
example: The Riemann Hypothesis is a conjecture about the zeros of the Riemann zeta function.

name: Eta
meaning: Often used to denote efficiency in physics or elasticity in economics.
example: The efficiency, eta, of this engine is about 30%.

name: Theta
meaning: Commonly used to represent an angle in geometry or a parameter in statistics.
example: We need to find the angle theta to calculate the projectile's trajectory.

name: Iota
meaning: Less common, but can represent an inclusion map in mathematics.
example: The iota subscript is used in some notations for Greek vowels.

name: Kappa
meaning: Used to denote curvature in differential geometry or connectivity in graph theory.
example: Cohen's kappa measures inter-rater agreement for categorical items.

name: Mu
meaning: Represents the population mean in statistics or the coefficient of friction in physics.
example: The average height (mu) of the population is 175cm.

name: Nu
meaning: Used to represent frequency in physics or degrees of freedom in statistics.
example: The frequency nu of the light determines its color.

name: Xi
meaning: Used to denote a random variable or a position vector.
example: The partition function in statistical mechanics is often denoted by Xi.

name: Omicron
meaning: Rarely used to avoid confusion with the number 0. Sometimes used in complexity theory for little-o notation.
example: This algorithm's complexity is little omicron of n-squared.

name: Rho
meaning: Represents density in physics or the correlation coefficient in statistics.
example: The density rho of water is approximately 1000 kg/m³.

name: Tau
meaning: Represents torque in physics, a specific type of shear stress, or a time constant.
example: The torque, tau, required to tighten the bolt is 50 newton-meters.

name: Upsilon
meaning: Used in particle physics to denote the Upsilon meson.
example: The Upsilon particle is composed of a bottom quark and its antiquark.

name: Chi
meaning: Used for the Chi-squared distribution in statistics or magnetic susceptibility in physics.
example: We performed a chi-squared test to check if the results were significant.

name: Psi
meaning: Represents the wave function in quantum mechanics or the polygamma function in mathematics.
example: The square of the psi function gives the probability of finding a particle at a certain point.

name: Omega
meaning: Represents angular velocity in physics, the last ordinal number, or an asymptotic lower bound in complexity theory.
example: The angular velocity omega of the spinning top is decreasing.

name: If and only if
meaning: A shorthand for the biconditional logical connective ↔.
example: A polygon has three sides iff it is a triangle.

name: Without loss of generality
meaning: Indicates that the proof assumes something for simplicity, but that the argument holds for all cases.
example: W.L.O.G., assume the first number is the largest; the same logic applies if any other number is largest.

name: Quod Erat Demonstrandum
meaning: Latin for 'what was to be shown', traditionally placed at the end of a mathematical proof.
example: ...and therefore, all even numbers are divisible by 2, Q.E.D.

name: Such that, So that
meaning: A common abbreviation used to introduce a condition or constraint.
example: Find all numbers x s.t. x is greater than 5.

name: Sequence, Tuple
meaning: An ordered list of elements.
example: The coordinates are represented by the sequence ⟨x, y, z⟩.

name: Closed Interval
meaning: The set of all real numbers between a and b, including a and b.
example: The temperature range for the experiment is [10, 20] degrees Celsius.

name: Open Interval
meaning: The set of all real numbers between a and b, excluding a and b.
example: The acceptable margin of error is in the open interval (-0.1, 0.1).

name: Measured Angle
meaning: Used to denote the measurement of an angle.
example: The measured angle of the ramp is 15 degrees.

name: Satisfies
meaning: A model satisfies a formula if the formula is true in that model.
example: The model of a sunny day satisfies the statement 'The sun is shining'.

name: Equal by definition
meaning: Indicates that the equality is true by definition.
example: Profit is equal by definition to revenue minus costs.

name: Floor function
meaning: The greatest integer that is less than or equal to x.
example: If you have 4.7 pizzas, the floor function says you have 4 whole pizzas.

name: Ceiling function
meaning: The smallest integer that is greater than or equal to x.
example: If you need 4.2 gallons of paint, the ceiling function means you must buy 5 gallons.

name: Prime, First Derivative
meaning: Lagrange's notation for the first derivative of a function f.
example: The prime symbol indicates the rate of change, like the speed of a car.

name: Double Prime, Second Derivative
meaning: Lagrange's notation for the second derivative of a function f.
example: The double prime indicates the rate of change of the rate of change, like the acceleration of a car.

name: Independence
meaning: Two events are independent if the occurrence of one does not affect the probability of the other.
example: The outcome of two consecutive coin flips are independent events.

name: Covariance
meaning: A measure of the joint variability of two random variables.
example: The covariance between height and weight is positive, as taller people tend to be heavier.

name: Correlation
meaning: A normalized measure of the linear relationship between two random variables, between -1 and 1.
example: The correlation between study time and exam scores is strong and positive.

name: Is distributed as
meaning: Indicates that a random variable follows a specific probability distribution.
example: The height of adult males is distributed as a normal distribution.

name: Normal Distribution
meaning: A continuous probability distribution that is symmetrical around its mean, often called the bell curve.
example: Test scores in a large class often follow a normal distribution.

name: Uniform Distribution
meaning: A probability distribution where all outcomes are equally likely.
example: The outcome of a single roll of a fair die follows a uniform distribution.

name: Interior of A
meaning: The largest open set contained in A.
example: The interior of a fenced yard is the grassy area, not including the fence itself.

name: Boundary of A
meaning: The set of points which can be approached both from A and from the complement of A.
example: The boundary of a country is its border.

name: Approaches, Tends to
meaning: Indicates that a variable approaches a specific value in a limit.
example: As time approaches infinity, the speed of the decelerating car tends to zero.

name: Hadamard Product
meaning: An element-wise product of two matrices of the same dimensions.
example: The Hadamard product can be used to apply a filter to an image in digital image processing.

name: Coproduct
meaning: A construction that is the dual of the product; for sets, it is the disjoint union.
example: The coproduct of the set of cats and the set of dogs is a new set containing all cats and all dogs, where each animal's origin is tracked.

name: Product
meaning: A construction that generalizes concepts like the Cartesian product of sets or the direct product of groups.
example: The product of the set of shirt styles and the set of pant styles gives all possible outfits.

name: Set of morphisms
meaning: The collection of all arrows (structure-preserving maps) from object A to object B.
example: In the category of people, Hom(Alice, Bob) could be the set of all ways Alice can communicate with Bob.

name: Objects of a category
meaning: The collection of all objects in a category C.
example: The objects of the category of a subway system are the stations.

name: Biproduct
meaning: A construction that is simultaneously a product and a coproduct.
example: In the category of vector spaces, the direct sum is a biproduct.

name: N-ary Intersection
meaning: The intersection of a collection of sets.
example: The list of students enrolled in all three required classes is the n-ary intersection of the three class rosters.

name: N-ary Union
meaning: The union of a collection of sets.
example: The master list of all club members in the school is the n-ary union of the membership lists of all individual clubs.

name: Disjoint Union
meaning: The union of a collection of pairwise disjoint sets.
example: A library's collection is the disjoint union of its fiction and non-fiction sections.

name: Right Semidirect Product
meaning: A way to construct a new group from two groups, one of which acts on the other.
example: The group of symmetries of a square can be constructed as a semidirect product of the rotation group and a reflection group.

name: Left Semidirect Product
meaning: A way to construct a new group from two groups, one of which acts on the other.
example: The Euclidean group of motions (rotations and translations) is a semidirect product.

name: Group generated by S
meaning: The smallest subgroup containing the set S.
example: The group of integers under addition is generated by the set {1}.

name: Center of a group
meaning: The set of elements that commute with every element of the group.
example: The center of a group of people at a round table would be those who can switch places with anyone else without changing the group's overall arrangement.

name: Commutator subgroup
meaning: The subgroup generated by all the commutators, measuring how far the group is from being abelian (commutative).
example: For a commutative group like addition of numbers, the commutator subgroup is just {0}, because the order of operations never matters.

name: id est (that is)
meaning: Used to provide clarification or restate something in different terms.
example: The final exam is comprehensive, i.e., it covers all topics from the semester.

name: exempli gratia (for example)
meaning: Used to introduce one or more examples.
example: Many countries are in the northern hemisphere, e.g., Canada, France, and Japan.

name: Succeeds or is equal to
meaning: An element comes after or is the same as another in a partial order.
example: In a project timeline, the testing phase succeeds or is equal to the build phase (it can't start before).

name: Precedes or is equal to
meaning: An element comes before or is the same as another in a partial order.
example: To qualify for the next round, your score must precede or be equal to the top score.

name: All equal to
meaning: Indicates that all items in a set are equal.
example: For a fair distribution, the shares must be all equal to each other.

name: End of Proof (Tombstone)
meaning: A modern symbol used to mark the end of a mathematical proof.
example: ...which completes the argument. ∎
